Award.AwardTitle: Stationary Phases for Liquid Phase Separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Luis A. Colon of the University at Buffalo to develop stable separation media based on highly crosslinked polymeric layers on silica for use in separation techniques in chemical analysis. Separation media are indispensable analytical tools in chemical analysis, which is itself central to the chemical, biological, and related sciences. The proposed crosslinked polymeric layers are designed to possess high chemical and physical stability, with the goal of improving upon currently used separation materials. The proposed research is targeting a universal platform on which different separation media could be prepared, opening up possibilities for their use in specific practical applications. Broader impacts are addressed through the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, including members of traditionally underrepresented groups. Research on this project will provide skills in chemical analysis that are very useful for the modern-day workforce in the academic, pharmaceutical and industrial chemical sectors. Experiments will be developed for the undergraduate laboratory so that more students can experience an authentic research experience in this setting.

The research project will exploit the chemistry of diazonium salts to assemble organic molecular entities on the surface of silica substrates, rendering materials with highly desirable properties for liquid chromatography (LC) and other separation techniques, dictated by the newly assembled layer on the material's surface. The strategy consists on attaching functionalized aryl groups on the silica surface, from which molecular layers will grow by means of diazonium chemistry, and then crosslinking the layers to create a highly stable polymer layer on the silica surface. During the different stages of optimizing the synthesis of the new layer on the silica surface, a systematic evaluation will be performed to assess the physical, chemical, and chromatographic properties of the material using a battery of techniques (e.g., Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, elemental analysis, gas adsorption analysis, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis). LC will be used to examine the chromatographic performance of the newly synthesized materials. The assessment will include the use of standard published protocols that will provide information on the retentive behavior (i.e., selectivity) and stability of the materials under liquid chromatographic conditions. These investigations are part of a long-term research program focused on the study of new and improved materials for chemical analysis, particularly in chemical separations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project was focused on advancing the knowledge in the area of materials science as it applies to new/improved adsorbent media for molecular separations in the liquid phase. The rich chemistry of diazonium salts was exploited to chemically modify the surface of silica particles, creating a new rigid, highly cross-linked polymeric layer on the surface. The newly assembled layer on silicas was characterized using various techniques. The rendered silica materials proved to have highly desirable properties for liquid chromatography, a separation technique that is indispensable in chemical analysis. The silica material was shown to possess a mix-mode of interactions where the adsorption of polar versus non-polar compounds could be varied by controlling the experimental conditions of the liquid phase. In this regard, it showed to be useful in the separation of both hydrophobic and hydrophilic compounds. The modified silica particles packed in chromatographic columns showed to be highly stable under acidic mobile phase conditions and at elevated temperatures (i.e., 80 oC). Such stability surpasses that of silica materials modified by most conventional approaches. In addition, the thin layer on silica provides a means for further chemical functionalization which allows the formation of silica surfaces with different chemical properties useful for selective separation of a variety of chemical compounds, while preserving its chemical stability. The results of the investigations have been disseminated via peer review publications in the open scientific literature and in presentations at scientific conferences and/or seminars at universities.

The project also served to train graduate and undergraduate students in modern laboratory research practices, technology, and instrumentation for chemical analysis. This included bringing faculty and students to the PI?s laboratory from a four-year college that is composed of students of a predominantly underrepresented minority group in science. Time was devoted to improving teaching and learning by creating new discovery-based laboratory experiences for the undergraduate curriculum. The research activities also provided for the education, development, and training of new scientists. Under this project, 11 graduate students, and 3 undergraduates, had the opportunity to participate in one or more aspects of the research endeavors, contributing to their educational training and development in technical areas. Of these, 8 are members of underrepresented minorities; this reflects an increase participation of such groups in the STEM fields. The students were trained in highly sophisticated techniques and instrumentation of modern science. Within the grant period, 5 students obtained the PhD degree and one master?s degree in chemistry; they have joined the skillful technical workforce of the country. 

In all, this project has provided the means to study several important issues, advancing the knowledge in material chemistry for separation science with immediate impact in chemical analysis. In addition, the project provided the vehicle to train and educate a diverse group of students while they pursued advanced degrees in science, preparing them to join the technology and knowledge-driven workforce of their generation.
